Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim Terway
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim Terway
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim Terway
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Same as TF

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Absolutely wonderful

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim was really well organized and integral to guiding the class along. He was also very accessible outside of class and I really liked speaking with him about concepts that I found very complex and needed help breaking them down.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Strengths: thoughtfully and clearly translated Susan's remarks in a easy to understand way. Weakness: sometimes portrayed material in an exclusive way.

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim is straightforward, hilarious, perceptive, and brilliant. He kept our class on track. He has high expectations of students but is always kind and generous with his time, and endlessly receptive to questions. He really helped me learn how to maintain an actively open mind. Should he choose to pursue it, he will make a really wonderful professor someday.

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim was generally excellent. I appreciated his availability and willingness to discuss in depth concepts only lightly touched on in class. The comments below are intended to help him improve, given that he is already a very promising teacher. Tim could improve his teaching mostly in the class room setting (he is, as noted above, very helpful one-on-one). In the classroom, Tim has a tendency to dilute the core of his message by frequently alluding to its importance, sophistication, or erudition -- this gets in the way of actually teaching the core idea. Similarly, Tim can dominate classroom discussion by lecturing in a way that does not invite questions. This is a tricky concept because it is not tied to whether or not he solicits questions (which he makes a clear effort to do), but rather to the way that he comports himself as a speaker. In a nutshell, I think Tim is so eager to offer his own answers to student questions that the actual process of questioning on the student's end can be curtailed.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Sometimes the teaching style was not conducive to learning (long, dry lectures with little discussion or case study examples), but I think that both Tim and Susan have been very receptive to student feedback regarding this. I also think Susan might help the class by listening more to students input and concerns...sometimes it feels like she talks over us.

This class was the most important course I have taken at Yale FES. It helped me to understand what policy is... and how to understand the process in its entirety. I am excited to have this in my pocket as I move forward with my career. Much for the material seems like common sense... but has a way of being really hard to talk about.

This course is extremely useful as a whole. The framework that it introduces is valuable, and Susan and Tim have done a very good job getting to the meat of it in a single semester such that students walk away with a complete skill set ready for application. No other course I have taken this semester does such a good job providing a thorough, actionable, foundation in a novel skill. Tim and Susan are both generally excellent teachers in my experience. I found both very willing to answer questions outside of class and provide the support and resources I needed to master the concepts being taught. Question 11: The greatest area for improvement here is in the tenor of the course. Susan and Tim both spend a lot of time promoting the importance and utility of their ideas... this is not necessary in my view--the quality of the content speaks for itself--and the frequent promotion detracts from the quality of their teaching.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: A lot of new material
Getting to dig into a case study and learning about other student case studies.
Talking about current events -- diversity issues -- in the context of this framework. And applying this framework to case study I care about deeply.
Great framework for tackling any environmental or social problem. I feel like I now have a great toolbox in my pocket ready to deploy if I get into a jam.
This course has many very strong elements. Outside discussion groups, the case study project, and homework projects (Occurring World, Listening World) were all tremendously useful.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Class discussions and lecture presentations of information.
Allow the students to lead and engage in discussion... the instructors should wait longer before diving in and directing the conversation.

Dr. Clark is responsible for an incredibly useful course that has no equivalent at FES and for allowing for a wonderfully communal and inclusive feeling in the classroom. However, she often cuts students off halfway through their questions in a way that seems really antithetical to the philosophy of respect and inclusion that she preaches.

The classroom component of this course is its weakest. As mentioned earlier, I feel that the utility of the policy sciences is evident to students as they begin to master it. Relative to the case study, discussion groups, and homework exercises, I felt that the classroom sessions were relatively less useful, principally because of the amount of time spent promoting the ideas being covered rather than focusing solely on teaching them. Even so, the classroom component of this course still compares favorably to the classroom component of similar courses I took this semester.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Discussion group and lectures are guided by the same weekly reading list. The two components work well together.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course is an excellent primer for working in policy, examining policy issues throughout our time at F&ES.
Great framework for tackling any environmental or social problem. I feel like I now have a great toolbox in my pocket ready to deploy if I get into a jam.
This course is central to my overall program of study. I am using it to develop a framework for integrating the various fields of study I am pursuing at FES into a single cohesive skill set.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To think
Close friends have really enjoyed Susan's classes. I am passionate about creating successful public outreach and conservation projects.

When I went to the course during shopping period, I could tell it was going to be a mind-bending experience. Several of my other courses were quantitative, 'hard-skills' based, and I wanted to make sure my mind stayed open to different ways of thinking. I took the class during my first semester and I think it will provide a great base from which to approach future courses, projects, and environmental problems.
See above. The course advertised itself as providing a framework for integrating diverse areas of knowledge to inform good natural resource management and policy, and has delivered on that promise.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
YES!
Yes.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Helped to break down readings and evaluate what we were learning on an ongoing basis.

Advantages -- talking through class concepts and my case study with my group; great feedback Disadvantages -- it would have been nice to have met with other groups throughout the semester to gain difference perspectives.
Really enjoyed the Monday group meetings; low stress way to bounce thoughts off each other and get our minds organized. Also contributed to the lovely community feeling begun in the classroom.
The discussion group I participated in was excellent.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I would highly recommend it!
Take it. Stay with it. It makes sense at the end of the term. And people of all interests and backgrounds would benefit from this course.

Take the course. If my experience is any indicator, this course will be a tremendous asset. HOWEVER, be clear on what you expect to get out of it, and judge for yourself whether it delivers (to this point, try not to worry about the amount of time spent promoting the class-- your own judgement is what is important here).
